There is also a small private airstrip located in Heth Township, called Robertson Airpark. It is mainly used for private aircraft and small planes, but also is utilized by recreational use such as skydiving. Heth Township is located within Harrison County, making it a great place to experience some of the local culture and scenery. The nearby Kunkel's Mill Covered Bridge is located within Heth Township and is a historic landmark. The area is popular with outdoorsmen and nature enthusiasts who visit the nearby Harrison-Crawford State Forest, located 15 miles south of Heth Township. Heth Township is a unique and beautiful area in Harrison County, Indiana. It is a combination of rural farmland, wooded areas, and small towns, all with their own history and culture.

Prosopometamorphopsia is a rare and rarefied condition characterized by the individual's visual perception of other people's faces transforming into the faces of familiar figures, often beloved family members, friends and even animals. The condition has been termed "Metamorphopsia of the Human Face" and is often associated with temporal lobe epilepsy. It was first acknowledged by neurologist and psychiatrist Auguste Bouisson in 1878. People affected by prosopometamorphopsia often first notice the faces of loved ones, such as parents, siblings or children, morphing into the faces of different individuals as they look away from the person and back again. In some cases, the face will change instantaneously, or even switch back and forth between two or more individuals, such as a parent and a pet. In other cases, the transformation occurs slowly and with notable changes in the features seen in the face. The condition is not associated with visual hallucinations, as those affected by prosopometamorphopsia can clearly distinguish between the shifting faces and the actual person in question. It is more likely an issue with visual processing in the brain, as people with temporal lobe epilepsy often experience this issue. This is due to the way in which images and faces are processed, stored and retrieved in the brain, resulting in the misperception that someone's face has changed when it has not. Though prosopometamorphopsia is comparatively rare, it can have a serious impact on social situations. Those affected may become apprehensive of unfamiliar people or environments, as they fear seeing their faces transform. This fear can make socializing, attending social events and going outside difficult for those with the condition. Fortunately, medical professionals are beginning to address this condition. Various treatments are available, including medications, cognitive behavioral therapy and, where necessary, physical therapy. In addition, patients may benefit from support from family and friends, as well as group sessions with individuals who are also affected. Though prosopometamorphopsia remains relatively unknown, it is an increasingly recognised condition. As medical professionals become aware of the symptoms and impact it can have, those affected by it can receive the medical and emotional help they need to manage their condition.

The Lithuanian Supercup is a one-off match in Lithuanian football held at the beginning of the domestic season. The match is contested by the previous season's A lyga and Lithuanian Football Cup winners. There are no promotions or relegations and the trophy is awarded to the winner of the match. The first edition of the Lithuanian Supercup was held in 1994, when FK Žalgiris won the match against FK Vaidotas; the match finished 2–0. FK Žalgiris have by far been the most successful team in the competition, having emerged victorious in 8 of the 24 editions of the Supercup to date. Atlantas Klaipėda hold the record of being the second most successful team, as they have won the match on four occasions. The 24th edition of the Lithuanian Supercup was held on 16 July 2017 in the Lithuania Megal, with FK Trakai victorious over FK Žalgiris with a 3–2 score in extra-time. Mindaugas Žužas scored all of FK Trakai's three goals in the match, which made him the top scorer of the Supercup till now. The most unifying feature of the 24 editions of the Lithuanian Supercup has been the attendance. Substantial crowds, averaging around 10,000, have come from all over the country to watch the match and cheer on the two teams. In fact, the largest crowd ever found in a Lithuanian Supercup match was in 2010 when nearly 20,000 people attended the match at the LFF Stadium in Vilnius. In recent years, the Lithuanian Supercup has become an event for entertainment and marketing for Lithuanian businesses. Many businesses have sponsored the match in order to promote their companies and boost sales. Additionally, the match has become a medium for promoting various sports clubs and teams, with many clubs using the match to announce their new signings and players. Thus, the Lithuanian Supercup has evolved into a much more than just a match between two teams aiming to win the trophy. It is now a major event in Lithuanian football and a platform for various businesses and teams to culminate their efforts to promote football in the country.

The 1888 Open Championship was the 28th Open Championship, held 14–15 June at Prestwick Golf Club in Prestwick, South of Scotland. The Championship was won by Jack Burns, who scored 167 to win the tournament by three shots over runner-up Willie Campbell. The event was the final Open Championship to be played over 36 holes, switching to 72 holes the following year. This tournament marks the first instance in any major tournament of two professional golfers playing as partners. The pairing of Willie Park Sr. and Mungo Park was a successful one, as they finished in third place with a score of 172. With an additional professional partner, John Ball, the team shot a far more respectable score of 168 for the two rounds. A total of 48 players entered the Championship, and the winner received a prize of £10. The competition was divided into two divisions with the top sixteen players (selected according to their listed handicaps) competing in the first division and the remaining players competing in the second division. The course at Prestwick, a classic Scottish links course, was notorious for being a demanding test of golf. In the first round of play, the winds were gusty and combined with the deceptively difficult greens, which Jack Burns described as “lightning fast” to putt on, the course proved to be a stern test. Burns and Campbell, who started the final round tied, broke away from the field with a score of 82 and 79, respectively, in the second round, with Burns shooting a consistent round of 81, 83 to take the title. The Scottish dominance of the Open Championship as well as golf in general was clear with the top four finishers all being Scottish. This dominance was due in part to the small field size as compared to other events and the fact that the event was not well known outside of Scotland at this time. This was Jack Burns’ second and final victory in the Championship, having previously won in 1880. He is one of only two players to win the Championship twice, the other being Willie Park Sr.. The 1888 Open Championship was the final Open Championship to be held at Prestwick prior to the introduction of the Open Championship’s rota system in 1895.

Shruti (from Sanskrit श्रुति, meaning "tone, sound") is a concept in Indian classical music, referring to the smallest semitone of the raga or melody. It is an essential part of the musical system of India and is the basis for all melody and harmony in Indian music. Shruti refers to the microtones between melodic notes, which are notated using quarter-tone notation. In order to perform a given raga, musicians must be very well-versed in the structure and technique of using these microtones, which require a greater degree of accuracy than regular semitones. Indian instruments such as the sitar, tabla and veena are tuned to particular shrutis, which are very particular frequencies. Some Indian systems have 12 shrutis, based on the 12-semitone division of the octave. There are two categories of shrutis, Shuddha and Vikrut, or "natural" and "altered." Shuddha shrutis are the pitches of the seven basic swaras of the Octave, while Vikrut shrutis are more finely tuned microtones that occur between the basic swaras. In Indian music, musicians use the shrutis to create a feeling of movement in the music, as well as to set a mood or create an atmosphere. In addition, the differences between various shrutis can be used to create a certain kind of tension. This is why they are so important to Indian classical music and why they play such a large role in Indian musical tradition. In recent years, shrutis have been used in western music as well, combining different musical genres. However, this is still a relatively novel concept and its usage is still in its early stages. Shruti is an ancient concept and it has been around for centuries. It is a fundamental part of Indian music, and it is important for musicians to understand and master the art of using shrutis in order to perform a given raga or melody in the most authentic way. This is why shrutis are so important to Indian music and have continued to be so for so long.

Dennington is a small village and civil parish situated in the Waveney Valley, in the county of Suffolk, England. The village has a population of about 640. It is located about 13 miles (21 km) south of Norwich. The village can be traced back to at least 1050 A.D. and the Domesday Book of 1086, in which it is recorded as Denitone and belonging to William d'Ecouis. Dennington was changed to Deninctune by the 13th century. The village is nestled between two hills, known as the "Dennington Hills" and is known to be one of the most picturesque villages in the area. The church of St Mary, the oldest building in the village, dates back to the 12th century. It is a grade one listed building with a Norman font, 15th century oak screen and a remarkable stained glass window by Edward Burne-Jones. The village has a pub, a post office, a village hall, a primary school and a veterinary surgery. The former Dennington Railway, which was opened in 1887 was closed in 1966. The disused railway line serves as a path for walkers and cyclists and has provided an important ‘green corridor’ for wildlife. The village is home to the Dennington Wildlife and Bird Trust, a nature reserve which spans across two sites owned and managed by the Trust. The reserve consists of coppiced woodland, species-rich grassland, an old quarry and a lake. A wide variety of wildlife and plants can be found at the reserve, including dormice and otters. The village holds an annual flower show and the Dennington Village Society is active in promoting the interests of the local community. There are also regular talks, events and activities by various supports groups, such as Dennington Footpaths and Dennington Youth Group. The neighbouring village of Peasenhall is home to the Peasenhall Peasant, a scarecrow festival, also known as "The Big Scarecrow Weekend", which is held every year in May. In 2018, the village was chosen to be featured in the BBC half-hour documentary series Village of Dreams. The documentary followed local couples, who have been part of the community for generations, and showcased the lives and traditions of the village. The village is served by a regular bus service to nearby towns, with further rail and road links connecting it to Norwich and Ipswich. Overall, Dennington is a beautiful and peaceful village, combining traditional rural life with modern amenities and is home to a friendly and welcoming community.

Szkieve (pronounced: sk - ee - vuh) is a furry sci-fi/fantasy artist, illustrator and writer. They are best known for their webcomic, Path of the Dragon, and their cover art for books such as the Horned Rat series by Neal Asher. Szkieve was born in Poland and grew up living in Croatia, with regular visits to the United States. They are currently residing in Portland, Oregon. Szkieve has been creating art since the age of five and cites the influence of Disney movies and animated shows from their childhood as the starting point for their work. Szkieve initially found success in the online art community by promoting their artwork through auctions, commissions, and drawings placed in print media. This led to an invitation in 2014 to attend the AnthroCon convention in California as a special guest. Since then, they have become a regular speaker and panelist at conventions throughout the USA, Europe and Asia. In 2015, Szkieve started the webcomic "Path of the Dragon", in which they explore high fantasy with anthropomorphic characters. It quickly gained a large following and was featured in the anthology "Anthrobunny". In addition to their original work, Szkieve's illustration portfolio includes cover art for novels such as the Horned Rat series by Neal Asher, "The Witch of Erfurt" by Vincent Capri and the "Sorceress's Phantom" by V.S. Dots. They have also collaborated with book publishers such as HarperCollins and Del Rey for book jacket illustrations. Aside from illustration and comics, Szkieve has also collaborated on various video game projects, such as the game "Earth Call" by Vulpine Games. In 2018, Szkieve launched the game "Ouroboros", a turn-based strategy game for which they served as Art Director. Throughout their career, Szkieve has garnered numerous awards, including "Best Anthropomorphic Cover Artist" from Ireland's Mostly Furry Things (2017) and the Silver Marker Award from Attic Reign (2020). In 2020, Szkieve was also included as part of the Out of the Ashes: Artists in the Making exhibition at the Portland Art Museum, featuring a particularly dynamic piece comprised of an illustration and a soundscape. Szkieve is an artist who has dedicated themselves to the world of furry illustration, cover art, comics and beyond. Their light-hearted, bold art has brought joy to their supporters who have watched them grow and develop their craft over the years.

Joe Grey is an American entrepreneur, investor, engineer and philanthropist. He is most widely known for founding and leading Gray Wolf Exploration LLC, an energy exploration and development company. Joe Grey was born in Houston, Texas on June 15, 1980. He began studying engineering at the University of Texas at Austin, but soon transferred to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) where he earned his bachelor's degree in Mechanical Engineering. After earning his degree, Grey worked as a research and development engineer at Schlumberger, a major oil services and technology firm. In 2007, Grey founded Gray Wolf Exploration. Under his leadership, the company became a leader in deposits exploration and exploitation. The company soon acquired a number of strategic assets, including a significant stake in the natural gas reserves of the Gulf of Mexico and onshore shale projects, leading to significant growth in the firm's operations. In less than a decade, Grey had built Gray Wolf Exploration into a major player in the energy industry, eventually merging the company with another oil and gas firm and selling it to Chevron for a reported sum of more than $225 million in 2017. Following the sale of Gray Wolf Exploration, Grey retired from active business and invested his money in philanthropic projects. Since then, he has devoted much of his time and resources to various charitable causes. He is considered an effective, generous philanthropist with a focus on improving education and alleviating poverty. Grey has also recently become involved in environmental causes, investing in sustainable energy initiatives and developing strategies to reduce carbon emissions. Apart from philanthropy, Joe Grey also writes books on entrepreneurship and investing and lectures at universities around the world. Having started his own business from almost nothing and grown it into a major success story, he is regarded as a highly sought-after mentor and advisor in the world of venture capital. Overall, Joe Grey is a successful entrepreneur, investor and philanthropist with a reputation as a quietly effective and generous contributor to charitable causes. His success, determination and ever increasing influence in the worlds of venture capital and philanthropy have earned him the admiration of many and he is quickly becoming a symbol of success and a model of leadership and philanthropy in the world of business.

Hebert High School is a public high school located in the city of Borger, Texas. It is part of the Borger Independent School District and serves 9-12 graders. The school's mascot is the Hebert Hawk and the colors are purple and gold. The school was established in the fall of 1971 and is named for the late educator W.D. Hebert. Hebert High School is proud of its academic and extracurricular achievements. The school is proud of its academic programs, including AP and IB courses, and its extracurricular activities, such as marching band, student council, and competitive sports. The extracurricular program also includes a variety of clubs and organizations such as National Honor Society and Spanish Club, as well as its own student-run newspaper, The Hawk. Hebert High School offers a variety of clubs and organizations such as Friends of the Arts, National Honor Society, National Technical Honor Society, StuCo, Design and Drawing, Spanish Club, Student Council, Ski Club, Anime Club and much more. In addition, the school has a rich tradition of athletic programs, hosting teams in football, basketball, swimming, soccer, baseball, softball, golf, track and field, volleyball, wrestling, and cross country. The athletic teams have enjoyed great success over the years, with the Hebert Hawks Football Team winning the 4A UIL State Football Championship in 2004. Hebert High School has strived to create an atmosphere of excellence and achievement. The principal, Mr. Paul Ruiz, is a strong advocate for providing a nurturing and safe learning environment for all Hebert Students. A variety of programs are available to support and encourage student learning, including the Hebert Honors Program, an internationally recognized education program that focuses on student achievement. Hebert High School offers a well-rounded educational experience and an extensive array of opportunities to learn and grow. The school provides students with a positive and supportive environment that encourages success both inside and outside the classroom. Hebert High School is a great place for students to discover their talents and reach their goals.

African Sources for African History is an academic field devoted to the study and use of historical records from within Africa to research and study African history. The field has developed significantly and grown in importance in the past few decades, due to an increased focus on African scholarship and the recognition of African history as a legitimate area of study. African Sources for African History encompasses a wide range of historical records, such as oral traditions, written texts, archaeological artifacts, monuments, and even visual records, such as paintings and photographs. It is essential that historians in the field recognize the different nature of each type of evidence, as the manner in which evidence is interpreted and understood can vary between different types. Oral traditions, passed down through generations, are an important source of African history. These traditions often provide insight into pre-colonial Africa, before the development of westernized written records. Historians are aware, however, that over time, these oral traditions can become muddled and misinterpreted; due to this, utilizing oral traditions as an authoritative source of evidence is often met with criticism. In terms of written records, archival research of both European and African sources has played a significant role in the study of African history. Colonial archives, such as those from the British, Portuguese, French and Dutch empires, often provide evidence on events that occurred during the colonial period, but may present a Euro-centric or skewed perspective. African archival sources, such as local newspapers, church records, and published accounts from Africans, are also an important part of the research. In some cases, even correspondence between local rulers is useful. Additionally, African historians in the field can also use memoirs, contemporaneous travelers’ accounts, oral accounts, and even court records as evidence. Archaeological records, such as tools, tools, jewelry, and pottery, provide evidence of the daily life and culture of pre-colonial Africa. Furthermore, monuments and architectural remains, such as ancient burial grounds, ruins of settlements and stone sculptures, are often studied to gain insight into the past. Visual records, such as photographs, paintings, and sketches, also provide evidence about African history and culture. Such records can often provide a glimpse into the past and show the many cultures that have existed in Africa over time. In conclusion, African Sources for African History is an important area of research and study, providing various records that shed light on Africa’s past, present, and future. As historians in the field gain more experience and expertise in deciphering different historical sources, the accuracy and qualitative nature of research pertaining to African history will likely only improve.

2012–13 Stoke City F.C. season is the 114th season of the English club Stoke City F.C. and their sixth season competing in the Premier League,the top flight of English football. It is their fifth consecutive season in the top flight of English football, since their promotion from the Football League Championship in the 2008/2009 season. The season began on 18 August 2012 with a 3–1 home win against Reading, and concluded on 19 May 2013, with Stoke losing 5–1 away at Southampton. The season saw Stoke finish in 13th place with 45 points. They reached the final 16 stage of the 2012-13 League Cup, saw Joe Allen make his debut for the club in a 2–2 draw against Arsenal and also saw the arrival of American defender Geoff Cameron as a new player addition to the beginning of the season. Stoke were eliminated from the FA Cup at the first knock-out stage, when they were beaten 3–1 at Anfield by Premier League leaders Liverpool. In December, Tony Pulis left the club by mutual consent, ending a near-eight-year tenure at Stoke City. He was replaced by Mark Hughes, who was appointed on a 3-year contract. In his last match, Stoke claimed a 4–0 win at home to Wigan Athletic – a scoreline that marked Hughes’ first match in charge. Player and staff overhauls saw the arrivals of Charlie Adam, Michael Kightly, Jack Butland, Jamie Ness, Marc Muniesa and Erik Pieters, whilst the season saw the departures of Michael Owen, Matthew Upson, Dean Whitehead, Rory Delap, Dave Kitson, Tuncay Şanlı, Wilson Palacios and Carlo Nash. Despite a difficult start, the season ended well under Hughes, with Stoke defeating Liverpool, Manchester United and Arsenal away from home, and lifting the club to a finish of 13th place in the Premier League. The club also announced a record turn-over of £78 million and the highest-ever position in the club's history - 46th in the Deloitte Football Money League. Overall, the 2012-13 was a successful season for Stoke, despite some mid-season turbulence. They finished the season strongly and even managed to secure a top-profit of £1.8m in the 2012/13 season. This was the first time in five years that Stoke City held a top profit rather than a loss in a Premier League season.

Used to Love is a song by Dutch DJ and producer Martin Garrix and Australian singer-songwriter Dean Lewis. Released on November 30, 2019, the track is the fourth single from Garrix's upcoming fourth studio album. The track starts out with Dean Lewis' soulful and melancholic vocals, followed by a lush and dance-like production by Martin Garrix. The two artists blend electronic and acoustic elements, which result in an emotion-charged song. The track is a melancholy yet upbeat electronica, exploring themes of emotional pain and break-up. Lewis shares his emotional trauma through his angelic vocals and speaks of a relationship that had gone wrong. Garrix accentuates and emphasizes the lyrics of Lewis' verses with a catchy chorus and a powerful blend of EDM and rock influences. The song has an inspirational tone of resilience, recognizing that breakups are uncomfortable but you must be strong, because life will continue to move on. The single was released for streaming and digital purchases on November 30, 2019. The accompanying music video was premiered on Martin Garrix's official YouTube channel on December 7, 2019. It was directed by Emil Nava and takes an experimental route with a unique narrative. The video follows the duo in an action-packed car chase, showcasing close-up shots of Garrix as he is racing on the highway. It received acclaim from music video critics and was described as a “distinct visual experience” by Billboard. The track performed well on the music charts, reaching number one in the UK Dance Chart and number three on the US Dance/Mix Show Airplay chart. It also peaked at number nine on the UK Singles Chart and number twenty-four in Australia. The single was also Grammy-nominated in the 2021 lineup, where it was in the running for "Best Dance Recording". Garrix and Lewis were two artists whose styles had already been well known before their collaboration, so Used to Love served as a reminder of their potential to make an inspiring and successful single together. The track is well-received by fans and critics alike and continues to be a fan favorite.

Yabba Dabba Doo! is an iconic catchphrase which originated in the American animated television series The Flintstones, the first major primetime animated series on television. It is typically used as a celebration of good times and was most famously uttered by the show’s main protagonist Fred Flintstone when excited. In addition to its use in The Flintstones, the phrase has become a popular cultural reference, with multiple uses in popular media and merchandise. The Flintstones aired for six seasons on ABC from 1960 to 1966, and was created by Hanna-Barbera Productions. Released in the same era as The Simpsons, it is believed to have greatly contributed to the success of primetime animation in the United States. The Flintstones centered around the Stone Age adventures of the titular family, who lived in the fictional town of Bedrock. and were comprised of Fred Flintstone, the breadwinner and husband, Wilma Flintstone, his wife, Pebbles Flintstone, their young daughter and Dino, their pet dinosaur. The catchphrase “Yabba Dabba Doo!” was introduced into the show in 1962 by Fred’s character as a way to express joy and excitement, and was said in reaction to moments like a successful golf swing or a beneficial spin in a game of chance. As the series progressed, the phrase began to take on a life of its own, appearing in promotional materials and other pieces of media outside of the show, such as statues and buttons. In addition to becoming a cultural icon in its own right, the saying has made appearances in various movies and television programs over the years. It was most recently used in an episode of the TV show Futurama, as well as an episode of The Simpsons. It has also been featured in songs and video games, such as in an update to the classic game Worms in which a character exclaims “Yabba Dabba Doo!” after victory. As well as its appearance in pop culture, the phrase has also been used to name various clothing brands, toys and other products. In 2010, a popular online clothing store, Yabba Dabba Doo!, was opened in the United Kingdom, and has since expanded to several countries over the years. The phrase has also been used in advertising campaigns and as the name of a beer brand produced by the American brewing company, Anheuser-Busch. In conclusion, “Yabba Dabba Doo!” has become an iconic phrase which has been embraced by the general public as a lighthearted way to show enthusiasm or happiness. Despite its humble origins in the 1960’s, the phrase has been adopted by modern cultures and is now used in various pieces of media, products, and advertisements.

Sandy Vee is a French DJ, songwriter and producer. A pioneer in the House music genre, Vee was a major influence on the global House music movement in the 2000s and 2010s. Sandy's first DJ residency was in Belgium in the late 1990s, quickly becoming a well known figure on the local and international House music scene. Throughout his career Sandy has had many different releases including his EPs 'Hide & Seek' and 'Without You'. These EPs showcased Sandy's signature house music style, an uplifting and feel-good sound with an emphasis on melody. His releases have been supported by some of the biggest names in the industry such as Armin van Buuren and Tiësto. Sandy is also responsible for remixing some of the biggest names in House, such as Steve Angello, Axwell and Eric Prydz. The sounds he creates have opened his music up to a much wider audience and gained him recognition from fans around the world. In addition to releases and DJ sets, Sandy has established his own label House For The People, which has seen him work with some of the top names in the industry as well as launching several successful singles. Sandy also regularly produces his own radio show, The V.I.P. Sessions, which connects music fans from around the world and has featured artists like Kölsch and Maceo Plex. Sandy Vee is considered to be one of France's best known and internationally respected House music producers. He has been instrumental in the success of EDM and club culture, always looking for new ways to push boundaries and help the genre evolve. He continues to inspire music fans around the world with his classic house sound and has established himself as a key figure in the industry.

Frank Archer (1837-1917) was an English politician. Born and raised in Manchester, he began his political career in local government, serving as a Councillor for Ardwick from 1887-1901. In 1901, he was elected to the House of Commons as a Conservative Member of Parliament for Manchester Rusholme, serving until 1906. Archer was a strong advocate for the economy and fiscal policy during his time as an MP, making important contributions to the Tariff Reform debate. He argued for a duty-free empire, land-tax reform and proposed a tax on luxuries in order to be able to reduce the burden of taxation upon the working classes. He was also a promoter of labour exchanges, which were aimed at managing the rising unemployment levels at the time. In addition to his work in the House of Commons, Archer was a strong supporter of the Temperance Movement and worked with others to promote it. He also campaigned actively for the issue of Women's Suffrage and was a member of the National Political Union, which fought for suffrage. Archer was a noted philanthropist and involved himself in many charitable organisations. He was President of the Manchester Philosophical Society and a member of the Manchester Medical and Manchester Royal Exchange Literary Societies. In addition to this, he was an active Freemason and held several offices. After his time in Parliament ended, Archer returned to local politics and served on various councils for local charities. He is remembered for his lifelong commitment to social reform and as an advocate of fiscal policy reform. During his retirement he wrote several books, starting his memoirs in 1906. Throughout his life, Archer was a respected figure in the political and social circles of Manchester. Upon his death in 1917, he was widely mourned, with a memorial being held in his honour at Ardwick Town Hall. Frank Archer serves as an example of the ideal of public service, dedicating his life to improving the lives of others.

Young Dan'l Boone was an American pioneer, hunter, and explorer who lived during the 18th century. He was the sixth of eleven children born to Squire Boone, III and Sarah Morgan Boone in the valley of Oley, Pennsylvania in 1734. As a youth, young Dan'l, as he was usually called, was a curious and eager learner. He showed an eagerness to explore the wilderness and to study the plants and animals he encountered. His parents took him and his siblings on hunting trips in search of game where he learned to use a rifle, to trap and to track wildlife. At the age of 15, young Dan’l moved with his family to the Yadkin River in what is now North Carolina. He enjoyed hunting and exploring the new land, but did not stay long. In 1750, the Boone family moved west to what is now Kentucky. Here, Dan’l was captivated by the wilderness, its beauty and its possibilities. His love of the wilderness, his courage and adventurous spirit made him a legendary figure in the American frontier. In 1767, after battling Native Americans, Dan’l attempted to settle on what is now the Kentucky River. He was unsuccessful, however, and in 1770, he led a group of settlers to the area that is now Boone County, Kentucky. He eventually became the first permanent European settler in the area. He built a fort he named Boonesborough, which soon became a refuge for many people fleeing Native American raids. For the remainder of his life, Dan’l explored, hunted, traded and fought off Native Americans as he traveled through the American frontier. He earned the respect of many of the pioneers who followed him and was a much revered figure in his day for his courage and resourcefulness. Young Dan'l Boone was one of the greatest American pioneers of the 18th century. He helped to open up the country to Western expansion and was one of the first to explore and settle Kentucky. His contributions to American life are remembered to this day and he will be remembered as an important part of the nation's history.

Judgment Day (2005) is a professional wrestling pay-per-view (PPV) event produced by World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE). It took place on May 22, 2005, at the HP Pavilion in San Jose, California. It was the seventh annual Judgement Day event. The main event featured John Cena defending the WWE Championship against JBL. Cena beat JBL to retain the WWE Championship after pinning him following an FU. The undercard featured five matches, including a no-contest between Eddie Guerrero and Rey Mysterio for the WWE United States Championship and an interpromotional match between Kurt Angle and Shawn Michaels. The event featured eight professional wrestling matches, each involving different wrestlers from pre-existing scripted rivalries and storylines. Wrestlers portrayed either heroes, villains, or reliant characters in the scripted events that built tension and culminated into a wrestling match. The first match of the show pitted Eddie Guerrero against Rey Mysterio for the WWE United States Championship. Midway through the match, both competitors were disqualified for using objects as weapons. The second match featured Booker T, Chris Benoit and Shawn Michaels in a Triple Threat match. Booker T pinned Benoit after a Scissors Kick to win the match. The third match saw Kurt Angle challenge Shawn Michaels in a "Battle of the Brands" Interpromotional Match. Angle won the match after pinning Michaels following an Angle Slam. The fourth match featured The Big Show against Muhammad Hassan in a Singles Match. Big Show won the match via pinfall by delivering a Chokeslam to Hassan. The fifth match pitted Phoenix and Melina in a Divas Tag Team Match. Phoenix and Melina won the match when Phoenix made Melina tap out to the Sharpshooter. The sixth match saw Charlie Haas challenging Chris Jericho for the WWE Intercontinental Championship. Jericho won the match after pinning Haas following a Codebreaker. The seventh match saw Edge and Randy Orton in a singles match for the World Heavyweight Championship. Edge won the match and the World Heavyweight Championship when he pinned Orton following a Spear. The main event saw John Cena defend the WWE Championship against JBL. Cena won the match, and retained the WWE Championship, after pinning JBL following an FU. Judgment Day (2005) was, in terms of buys, the lowest-selling Judgement Day event of all time. Critics have generally given negative reviews for the event, citing it as lackluster and uninteresting.

Old wave is a term coined in the late 2000s to describe the cultural wave of older music genres, specifically rock and metal. Many up-and-coming acts were attempting to recapture the sound of the old wave in a modern context. It is not to be confused with classic rock, which refers to a particular period in Rock and Roll which started in roughly the mid 60s and ended in roughly the early 80s. The revival of old wave genres started around 2005 when acts such as Steel Panther, Jet, Taking Back Sunday, The Darkness, and Franz Ferdinand began to gain popularity. These acts all had a tendency to take the classic, classic rock sound and lyrics and put them into a modern context by altering their instrumentation and production to fit the times. The new wave brought in a new audience who, after being saturated with processional pop music from the mid 90s onwards, sought to recover the musical "edge" that rock and metal had once possessed. Old wave has come to encompass a number of genres, including classic rock, hard rock, blues-rock, and metalcore. It can be heard in the sound of greats such as AC/DC or Led Zeppelin, but also in the sound of more modern bands like Halestorm or Disturbed. Generally, it is characterized as having an intense, rock-inspired sound, with particular attention being paid to guitar tones, song structures, and vocal delivery. Old wave has had a resurgence in the last decade, and its influence can be seen in the styles of younger bands such as The Pretty Reckless, Halestorm, and Ghost. Due to its blend of classic rock and metal influences, the genre appealed to a wider audience who were looking for something familiar, yet modern. Additionally, many of the acts that were developing in the scene have since gone on to great success, making old wave a viable style in popular music. Though old wave has made a big comeback in recent years, it is still considered to be on the fringe of mainstream music, and for the most part stays confined to specialty radio programs and independent media outlets. Its deep grooves, its blues-based guitar riffs, and its classic metal sound continue to inspire young bands, and will likely be heard for many years to come.

Lois Griffin (born August 5, 1957) is an American Politician who served as mayor of Quahog, Rhode Island until the 2006 election. Born in Quahog, She is the daughter of Robert and Barbara Pewterschmidt and the wife of Peter Griffin. She graduated from Quahog High School in 1975 and attended Brown University where she earned a double major in Political Science and Women's Studies. After returning to Quahog, she held a variety of jobs including waitressing in a restaurant, as a flight attendant, and working at the Quahog ferry. In 2000, she ran for mayor of Quahog, challenging incumbent Mayor Adam West. After two bruising campaigns, she won the election and was sworn in on January 2, 2001. During her tenure, Lois successfully brought infrastructure improvements to Quahog such as a new city hall, a new library, and renovations to the Quahog Museum. She also successfully lobbied for a new port authority and the Quahog Arts Council. However, her biggest success was her stewardship of the Quahog economy. During her tenure, Lois helped to bring additional revenue to Quahog in the form of a property tax rebate for homeowners. She also successfully lobbied for additional state funding for the University of Quahog and helped bring the Connecticut Carpet Company to Quahog. In 2006, Lois chose not to run for reelection and was succeeded by Adam West. After leaving office she accepted a teaching position at the Rhode Island School of Design and was appointed as a trustee on the Quahog Historical Commission. Lois is an active member of the Quahog Civic Society and the Rhode Island League of Women Voters. She also serves on the board of directors of the Quahog Community Foundation and is a frequent guest panelist at political forums at Brown University.

James Hodge Codding (October 18, 1869 - April 16, 1960) was an American minister who was ordained in the Presbyterian Church in 1892 and the most renowned Melanesian missionary. He was born in Verona, New York, and graduated from Hobart College in 1891. After traveling and teaching in the Melanesian Archipelago, he became superintendent and director of the London Missionary Society's South Seas evangelistic enterprise in 1902. He is credited with establishing the foundation for one of the largest and most successful missions in that region. Codding was sent to the South Seas by the London Missionary Society in 1895, where he spent the rest of his life working to bring the Gospel to the heathen over an immense range of islands known as Melanesia. During the span of his ministry in the region he planted over 160 churches and ordained 430 native pastors. He recorded more than one thousand names on his family register. The custom of head-hunting, common among the islanders at the time of Codding's arrival, was replaced by Christian worship services during his time there. He also popularized the phrase "sons of Solomon", which became the nickname of the islanders. In recognition of his missionary spirit, Codding was awarded an honorary doctorate in divinity by the University of Edinburgh in 1926 and the Order of the British Empire in 1928. In addition to his Christian message, Codding was a great social reformer and wrote numerous books and articles on Melanesian society. He wrote largely of his trials and tribulations as a missionary and his experiences in the "island world" as a form of cultural documentation. His works include: "Things Seen in the South Seas" and "Light in the Islands". Codding returned to California shortly before his death and is interred in the Forest Lawn Cemetery in Glendale. He had been a lifelong friend of the Roosevelt family, who attended his funeral. After his death, his widow, Ethel, hired a sculptor to create a bronze statue of Codding in San Francisco's Golden Gate Park. Codding is remembered today for his pioneering work in the South Seas. He helped to bring the Gospel to the regions of the Pacific islands, establishing educational and medical facilities, building churches and helping to reform island culture. His impact on the region can still be seen today in the islanders’ reverence for Christianity and the deep religious faith they practice. Codding will always be remembered as a great missionary, whose life and work left an indelible mark in the islands he visited.

Irving Lowens (June 2, 1910 – January 1, 1988) was an American musicologist, music historian, and archivist. He devoted his career to promoting and preserving traditional American and world music, working for the American Jewish Committee, the Cuneiform Records label, and the Library of Congress, where he was the Music Division's Curator from 1961 until his retirement in 1977. Lowens was born in New York City to a Jewish family. He attended public schools in Brooklyn, later receiving a B.A. from Brooklyn College in 1930 and a master's from Columbia University in 1932. While at college he was a member of Phi Beta Kappa and Sigma Alpha Mu. His initial career was as a music teacher, but from 1940 onwards, he was increasingly involved in research and archival work. In 1942, Lowens began working for the American Jewish Committee, first as a research secretary and later as a librarian and musical director for the Committee's concerts. During his time there, he worked to collect, preserve, and promote Yiddish and Hebrew music, including conductors such as the violinist Norbert Abner Glantz, the composer Yossele Rosenblatt, and the cantor America's first notable Cantor, Joseph Rosenblatt. But Lowens' involvement went beyond the realm of music. He had a strong interest in the early history of American Jews, particularly the so-called "hidden Jews" who lived in colonial America and were unaware of their Jewish identity. He researched and wrote about their history for a variety of publications and organisations. In 1961, Irving Lowens left the American Jewish Committee and was appointed Curator of the Music Division of the Library of Congress. During his time there, he lectured extensively and wrote several books, such as Music and Tradition: Essays in Honor of Irving Lowens (1973); A Guide to the Study of American Traditional Music (1976); and The Musical Legacy of the Lower East Side (1979). In 1975, he founded the American Music Center, which survived his retirement in 1977. Throughout his career, Lowens received many awards, including an Emmy Award (1974) for his work in collecting and preservation; the U.S. Library of Congress Research Prize (1985); and the Order of the Palmetto, South Carolina's highest honor (1985). In 1982, he became the first musicologist to be inducted into the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and he was also a Fellow of the Society for American Music. Lowens died on January 1, 1988, aged 77. He is remembered for his work in preserving the musical legacy of Jewish music, particularly the contributions of early American Jews, and his role in propelling American folk music into a respected field of study. His research on early American Jews has been widely honoured, and his name is often associated with the preservation and promotion of traditional music.

Albertanus of Brescia (ca. 1150 AD – 1225 AD) is a philosopher, theologian, poet, and theologian active during the 12th and 13th centuries, in the region of Lombardy, now part of northern Italy. He is most notable as the first to attempt to introduce the Aristotelian philosophy into the spiritual disciplines of Christianity. He was born into a relatively wealthy family in Brescia and spent his early adulthood in Lombardy. His primary education was in the Latin language and rhetoric. As a young man, he visited Paris, where he was exposed to the thought of the Arabic Latin authors of the twelfth century, such as Adelard of Bath, Peter of Spain, and John of Salisbury. It was through these authors that Albertanus was to learn about Aristotelian philosophy, for it was his belief that Aristotelian method could form the foundation of a theological system in harmony with the teachings of Christianity. After Paris, Albertanus travelled to the University of Padua, a veritable center of Aristotelian thought. It was here that he wrote his primary work, the Liber Paradoxorum, a book comprised of 274 maxims and paradoxes, many of them bearing a relationship to the Christian faith. Although his understanding of Aristotle may have been limited, what Albertanus did was lay the groundwork for future scholastic theologians and philosophers to embrace the works of the ancient philosopher. During the time of Albertanus, there were many forces in the Catholic Church that sought to reject the Aristotelian philosophy because it was viewed to be in opposition to the Christian faith. Therefore, the Church laid down harsh censures and sanctions upon any branch of intelligentsia that might align itself with the works of Aristotle. As a result, Albertanus lived under the fear of excommunication for much of his life. Nevertheless, he continued to use his knowledge of the philosopher for both religious and ethical interpretations. In 1222, John of Montecorvino, the first Franciscan missionary to the Far East, deemed him "the wise man of Brescia." After his death in 1225, Albertanus of Brescia was widely accorded much respect within the Church and one can especially find his influence in the sermons of Quodvultdeus, a Roman Catholic bishop. In addition, he is influential throughout Europe, especially amongst the scientists and philosophers of the Scholastic period. Today, the legacy of Albertanus of Brescia is still remembered, especially in Lombardy, where there are many statues and memorials that honor his life and work. Similarly, there is an annual celebration known as the “Festa di Albertano.” A modern statue of him is located in the main square of Brescia. Albertanus of Brescia, who had the courage to introduce Aristotelian thinking into a world of religious tradition and beliefs, stands as a symbol of courage and fortitude in the face of adversity. He is remembered as an individual who managed to rise above the constraints of his time and still contribute to the philosophical and theological development of the Middle Ages.

Julian Bugier (born April 11, 1977 in Nantes, France) is a French journalist and television news presenter. He is best known for being the anchor of the news program "20 Heures" on the French TF1 network from 2012 to 2020 and as co-host of the current affairs program "L'Emission politique" from 2017 to 2020. At the start of his career, Bugier hosted the morning shows during summer holidays on the channels France 3 and D8. In 2000, he became a presenter for the LCI channel for the news program "Le Grand Journal", which was presented by Claire Chazal. From 2005 to 2012 Bugier was the host of the morning program "Ça commence bien" on the channel TF1, a role he also took up in the evening news program "Le Journal de 17H" in 2008. From September 2012, Bugier was the presenter for the daily news program "20 Heures" on TF1 – the busiest newscast in the country. In 2017, he joined Anne-Sophie Lapix and Jean-Jacques Bourdin as co-host of the political debate show "L'Emission Politique" which aired on the channel "La Chaîne parlementaire". He also presents the news-roundup show "Weekend Direct" which airs on Saturday and Sunday afternoons. In addition to his roles in television news, Bugier is active on social media channels and participates in public debates and lectures. He has given many presentations on communication, digital media and audience engagement at Universities and business conventions. He has spent most of his career on the main channels of French television in various roles and has won numerous awards including two awards as best television news presenter at the "Marrakech international film festival". Aside from his television roles, Bugier is also recognised for his charitable and humanitarian contributions. He is an ambassador for several charities and initiatives, including the charity Les Petits Frères des Pauvres, the humanitarian organisation Téléthon, and the organisation to combat poverty and global warming (Greenpeace). In 2020, Julian Bugier announced he would be leaving TF1 after eight years of anchoring on the network. He was replaced by Jean-Pierre Pernaut for the "20 Heures" program, and by Stéphane Rozes for the "L'Emission Politique" show. Since leaving TF1, Bugier has focused on his social media activity and long-form journalism pieces, often related to current international events. In 2021, Bugier signed a deal with the streaming platform Salto, becoming their resident journalist and presenting the role of "Rédacteur en Chef" as a member of their team.

Fagan Park is a 64 hectare heritage park located on the north side of Galston Gorge in the Hills District of Sydney, Australia. It is bordered by the Galston Gorge to the east, the suburb of Galston to the north, and Arcadia Street to the west. Originally a large private orchard and property, the park was purchased by Hornsby Shire Council in 1936 for use as a public park. The park includes mature eucalypt and introduced trees, a series of walking routes and trails, a community hall, a playground, an outdoor gym, a skate park, picnic tables and benches, and three 'Fagan Park Pools': a man-made freshwater lagoon, toilet facilities and BBQ areas. Fagan Park is home to a variety of fauna, including birds, bats, wallabies, snakes and water dragons. The park also houses many historic structures, including two railway cottages (1864), Fagan Windmill (1864), an old wool shed and various heritage buildings such as the old Fagan Farmhouse (1890), a general store (1890), an apple packing shed (1920) and a refreshment kiosk (1930). The park is named after Daniel Fagan, an Irish convict who was granted 35 acres in the Galston area in 1836. He established a successful orchard and kept cattle and horses, and the Fagan family owned the land until its purchase by the Hornsby Shire in 1936. Since its purchase by the Hornsby Shire, Fagan Park has become an important community asset and recreation space, offering activities and facilities such as picnics, bushwalking, bird watching, swimming, water sports and exercising. In recent years, the park has become a popular spot for wedding ceremonies, with a range of landscaping, lawns and arbours providing an idyllic day out. Events are held throughout the year at Fagan Park, such as the Great Enchanted Picnic and our very popular ‘Music in the Park’. Festivals, concerts, outdoor theatre and outdoor cinema screenings also take place during school holidays and on public holidays. Fagan Park is a beautiful public park that elaborates and preserves the rich history and flora of the area. It is a unique area of special significance to the local community, and visitors from all over the world enjoy its various attractions.

Solar is a science fiction novel, written by Ian McEwan and published in 2010. It details the story of Michael Beard, a Nobel laureate physicist, who is struggling to stay relevant in a rapidly changing scientific climate. The novel explores Beard's life, relationships and circumstances as he embarks upon a journey of self-discovery. It covers his marital woes, his attempts at a mid-life career rejuvenation through an ambitious global warming project, and ultimately his moral dilemma between self-interest and ethical responsibility. The novel opens with an account of Beard's life in his 40s and recent past. He is married for the fifth time to a woman substantially younger than him. He is an acclaimed physicist and Nobel Laureate, but his reputation is beginning to dwindle as his research has become seemingly formulaic and unimaginative. Beard seeks to gain back some of his past success with an ambitious new project - applying quantum physics to global warming solutions. His research takes him to a remote island in the Arctic and as he applies his theories to the project, he finds himself in a deep moral quandary. His research demands compromise, compromise that proves too much for his moral compass. Soon, he finds himself trapped in a web of secrets and lies and a world of moral gray areas. The moral choices he makes have personal, professional and global implications. The novel has been praised for its attention to detail, the complexity of Beard's character and the masterful way in which McEwan weaves in current scientific theory with Beeard's personal journey. Solar is a thought-provoking and timely novel. It succeeds in elevating the global warming crisis and its personal and ethical implications from the realm of political discourse and into the human experience.

Jim Jamieson (May 27, 1956 – August 11, 2009) was a singer, songwriter, and guitarist from the United States. Jamieson is best known for his blues-rock influenced style of guitar playing, as well as his powerful singing voice. He was a prolific recording artist, releasing 10 albums between 1996 and 2008. Jamieson was born in St. Louis, Missouri and raised in Memphis, Tennessee. He began playing guitar at the age of nine. By the age of 12, Jamieson was already performing in local clubs throughout the city, and eventually earned the nickname "The Memphis Blue" due to his legendary blues performances. In the late 1970s, Jamieson joined the band BeBop Deluxe and toured Europe and the United States for two years. While with the band, he recorded two albums before returning to Memphis in 1981. When he returned to Memphis, he formed his own band and recorded several studio albums. He also performed at various clubs and festivals, including the prestigious New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival. During this time, Jamieson was also an in-demand guest on other artists’ albums, including renowned guitarist Eric Clapton’s Unplugged (1992) and The Complete Clapton (2007). In 1996, Jim released his first solo album, Trouble in Mind, and it was met with critical acclaim. Subsequent albums including Voodoo Guitar (1998), Hell & High Water (2000), and Crossroads (2002) solidified Jamieson's reputation as one of the most talented blues/rock musicians of his time. Throughout the decades, Jamieson was highly acclaimed by his peers and critics alike. He received six Grammy Award nominations between 1998 and 2007 and was inducted into the Memphis Music Hall of Fame in 1990. On August 11, 2009, Jim Jamieson died at the age of 83 after a long battle with cancer. He left behind a powerful legacy and lasting influence on the music scene. He will be remembered for his soulful and heartfelt guitar playing, and for being an inspiration to many aspiring blues-rock musicians.

Kevin Bramble (born February 7th, 1950, in New York City) is an American entrepreneur and businessman who is the founder and president of Bramble Holdings, a venture capital firm. Bramble grew up in Brooklyn, and attended New York University, obtaining a degree in finance and economics in 1974. After college, he served in the United States Army, where he was a staff sergeant. In 1978, he started a construction business that slowly grew into a successful venture. In 1986, Bramble formed Bramble Holdings, a venture capital firm. The primary focus of Bramble Holdings is to provide capital to promising startups. Operating as an angel investor, Bramble specializes in providing venture capital to early stage companies. Bramble has invested in dozens of successful startups, including at least two that became public companies. His investments span over 20 different industries, including digital media, healthcare, artificial intelligence, and retail. Bramble also acts as a mentor to entrepreneurs and regularly contributes to several incubators and accelerators. In addition to his venture capital firm, Bramble is also an active philanthropist. He is a major donor to the New York Public Library, the American Cancer Society, and to the Brooklyn Museum of Art. He is also the co-owner of the soccer team New York Cosmos. Bramble is active in the New York business community, and is a regular speaker at business conferences. He has been featured in numerous publications and television programs, including the Wall Street Journal, Forbes, and Fox Business News. Bramble has been married for over 38 years and has two children. In his free time, he enjoys playing guitar and tennis. He also enjoys traveling and has been to more than 25 countries.

Moonhole is a unique community located on the Caribbean island of Bequia in the Grenadine chain of islands. The innovative style of housing and community design was pioneered by the American architect Dr. Tom Johnson and his late wife/partner, Swedish artist and activist Claire Johnson. Moonhole is a one of a kind development with an ethically inspired ethos that calls for sustainable living and minimum footprint on the pristine landscape of Bequia. The Johnson’s vision articulated perfectly in the philosophy of their creation: “We are not taking from the peaceful island, we are just living in it”. Moonhole consists of approximately 10 private homes, including the Johnson’s own personal residence. Containing no straight angles of any kind, the homes were all handmade and carved from the existing coastline’s volcanic rocks, coral, and soft shale, with natural oils and sun-dried in the baking Bequia heat. The dwellings of Moonhole were designed by the Johnson’s with two key goals in mind, to create a minimal environmental footprint, and to allow nature’s wildlife to move through without confrontation. The homes are constructed in such a way that all surfaces slope downward, resulting in the adjacent coral reef becoming the roof and the pillars of the house which maximizes the low-disturbance natural building process. The vision of Moonhole aims to bring together all the virtues and principles of sustainable living with respect and in harmony with the environment. This concept is supported by the fact that Moonhole currently has no roads, no electricity and no phone lines, with guests and community members having to fly themselves to the island via private plane. In terms of architecture, Moonhole has no equal, in harmony with it’s enchanting surroundings it stands out as a beacon for sustainable innovation. Dr. Tom and Claire Johnson strove to create a utopian refuge that would showcase their pioneering beliefs, and the development at Moonhole is a living tribute to their mission and dedication.

William Farren Jr. (1813 - 1886) was an English actor and theatre manager best known for his involvement in several productions of plays by William Shakespeare. Born in London, Farren was the son of the prominent actor, William Farren Sr. and his second wife, Catherine Milbourne, who was also an actress. Farren made his theatrical debut at the age of eleven in Dublin, Ireland, where his father was performing a run of Shakespeare plays. After training at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art in London, Farren gained his first professional role in 1832 at the Theatre Royal, Dublin. Farren had considerable success on the stage in Britain and enjoyed a long career in the theatre. He appeared in a variety of roles, but is most noted for his portrayals of Shakespearean characters such as Hamlet, Iago in Othello and Malvolio in Twelfth Night. He also played smaller roles in farces and burlesques. In 1848, Farren set up his own theatre company, purchasing the lease of the Queen's Theatre, Haymarket, which he managed for five years. This venture was moderately successful and he staged a number of popular productions, including several plays by Shakespeare. In particular, Farren's popular production of The Tempest in 1849 is still regarded as being one of the best performances of that play. In addition to his stage career, Farren was also a prominent figure in the Staranciers or private theatrical clubs of the Victorian era. These clubs encouraged amateur dramatics and provided an opportunity for well-to-do Londoners to enjoy theatricals in private. At the same time, Farren acted as a mentor to many of the young performers. Farren retired from the stage in 1871 and went to live in Eastbourne in Sussex. He died at his home there in 1886 and was buried in St Nicholas's Churchyard, Brighton. He left behind a number of works including a three-volume autobiography which sheds light on his remarkable career. Despite his long career, Farren is today remembered mainly for his association with the production of Shakespeare plays, of which he was a great admirer.

Paul Schuitema (1897 – 1968) was a Dutch graphic designer, who is known for his modernist influences and advanced typographical innovations. He is considered to be one of the pioneers of modern graphic design and is renowned for creating iconic logos and posters. He was born in Zaandam, Netherlands, and studied at the Art Academy in Amsterdam. In 1924, he joined his father's company, the Schuitema Andijk Advertisers Corporation, in which he worked as a graphic designer until it closed in 1927. During this time he developed a modernist design style and prefigured Dutch graphic design. In 1931, he founded his own studio, Schuitema Grafisch Seminarium, in Amsterdam. He focused on modernist book designs, logos, labels, and posters and soon became a leader in the Dutch graphic design industry. Throughout the 1930s and 1940s Schuitema designed many logos and posters, which embodied his distinct style of abstract shapes, basic geometric forms, limited colours, and sans-serif typefaces. He is best known for his "DAF" logo, which he designed in 1933 for the Dutch automaker's first car. His logo for the Departement of Social Affairs consisted of three bars in black, yellow and blue and became widely utilized throughout the Netherlands. He also created a logo for the Dutch Civil Aviation Authority, which featured an airplane and horizontally striped wings, as well as a logo for Air France, which combined two short horizontal lines and an 'A' in the centre. In addition to playing a major role in influencing American and International design firms, Schuitema's work was integral in launching the modernist movement in Dutch graphic design. He was named the president of the Council for Art and Industry, which sought to promote modern art, design and architecture. In the 1950s, Schuitema was a major figure in the Amsterdam Art Group, an organization devoted to the promotion of graphic design and its role in visual communication. Schuitema's legacy has been widely celebrated and in 2006 he was inducted into the Dutch Hall of Fame for Graphic Designers. His contributions to the field of graphic design continue to inspire and influence modern practitioners.

Union Deposit, Pennsylvania is a census-designated place (CDP) in Dauphin County, Pennsylvania. The area, which falls within the Harrisburg–Carlisle Metropolitan Statistical Area, has a population of 2,092 as of the 2010 census. Union Deposit is named for the Union Deposit Bank, founded in 1874 by William Coleman, an early settler of the area. The name originates from the fact that William Coleman held half of the land in the area in trust for nearby religious expeditions. Union Deposit is a suburban town located only 5 miles from downtown Harrisburg. The area is primarily residential and features numerous businesses located mainly along Lincoln Highway East and Jonestown Road. The most notable places in Union Deposit are the Historic Union Deposit Inn, a truck stop and convenience store and the Union Deposit Fire Company, which oversees a volunteer fire company. The town is bounded on the north and west by Bressler, on the east by Rutherford and on the south by Conewago Township. Union Deposit is situated in the densely wooded hills of southern Pennsylvania, providing lovely scenic views and a quiet atmosphere reminiscent of a rural country town. Education in Union Deposit is provided by the Central Dauphin School District. A junior/senior high school and elementary school are both located within the Union Deposit area. The areas around Union Deposit are heavily wooded, making it perfect for hunting, fishing, and other outdoor recreation. The area is renowned for its wildlife, including deer, foxes, raccoons, and other game. Union Deposit is a small, peaceful community that is a wonderful place to call home. Residents enjoy the peace and quiet of living in the middle of the woods, as well as the close proximity to many of the larger cities in Dauphin County. With its rural atmosphere, beautiful views, and friendly residents, Union Deposit is a wonderful place to live and a great place to raise a family.

David Macklin (born October 10th, 1972) is an American former rower. Macklin competed in the 1996 Summer Olympics where he placed 20th in the men’s single sculls event. Macklin is a Massachusetts native and attended Deerfield Academy. He graduated from Princeton University in 2018 and remains active in Princeton’s boathouse coaching. Macklin was a decorated rower. He won the men’s single sculls gold medal at the 1993 FISU World Rowing Championships in Sheffield, England. He won the single sculls event at the 1994 World Cup Regatta in Munich, Germany and at 1995 World Cup Regatta in Munich. Macklin was also part of the men’s fours team that won gold at the 1995 Pan American Games in Mar del Plata, Argentina. Macklin made three Olympic teams (1992- Sydney, Australia, 1996- Atlanta, GA, 2000- Sydney, Australia). He won his heats in the men’s single sculls event in 2000 but was unable to place in the higher-level heats. Macklin was inducted into the Princeton Athletic Hall of Fame in 2018. He was cited for his long-term contribution to the Princeton Varsity lightweight rowing program and as a role model for rowers. Macklin is currently a firefighter in Boulder, Colorado. He is a husband and father of two children. Macklin’s dedication to athleticism has been an inspiration to generations of rowers and adventurers. He continues to inspire others with his capacity for hard work and his commitment to family and community.

Knut Alming (born October 26, 1950) is a Swedish songwriter, composer, and singer. Throughout his career, he has written and composed over 500 songs in the genres of Swedish folk, Swedish rock, pop, and blues. He is best known for his hit songs "Mamma och pappa", "Visa i gryningen", and "Det hjälper ingenting". Alming was born in Uppsala, Sweden, and grew up surrounded by music. His father was a singer, and his mother and aunts all sang in the church choir. He began writing and composing his own music in his teens, but it wasn’t until his twenties that he took up a career as a professional musician, writing and performing throughout Sweden. In 1984, he released his debut album, Jag ser Dig i mina drömmar. His first big hit single was the track “Mamma och pappa”, which became a top 10 hit on Swedish radio. Following this success, he released his second album, Som Sager Hos Mig in 1987, and the album included several hits such as “Visa i gryningen” and “Det hjälper ingenting”. His third album, I min ensamhet, was released in 1990 and was equally successful. Aside from his work as a songwriter and composer, Alming has also performed throughout Sweden, as well as in several other countries. In 2004, he began touring with his band, Knut Alming Band, and they quickly gained a large following. The band continues to tour to this day and is still highly popular throughout Scandinavia. In 2009, Alming was appointed a member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Music, and in 2011 he wrote and produced the hit single “Vi är samman”, which was used as a theme song for the European Union initiative “Best in Respect”. In 2016, he was the subject of a documentary, Knut Alming Lyckliga Dagar, which was screened at the Uppsala International Film Festival. Throughout his career, Alming has remained an important figure in the Swedish music scene. He has collaborated with several major artists, including Eric Gadd, Anna Sahlene, and Afro-Dite. His songs are known for their emotionally honest lyrics and heartfelt performances. He continues to write, compose and perform new music, as well as performing around Sweden and the rest of Europe with his band.

Tommy Randall (born April 6, 1979) is an American professional golfer from Naperville, Illinois. He currently competes on the PGA Tour. Randall began his professional golfing career in 2001, playing in PGA Tour qualifying school. He earned his PGA Tour card for the 2002 season, which he followed up with a successful 2003 season. He would go on to record four successful seasons on Tour before winning his first event, the 2007 Valero Texas Open. After this breakthrough win, Randall's career saw a number of highs and lows, but he continued to compete on the Tour. In 2009, Randall was diagnosed with Stage 4 colon cancer, forcing him to take a break from the professional golfing circuit. During his break, Randall underwent months of chemotherapy and radiation treatments, eventually succumbing to the disease in 2010. Since his passing, Randall has been immortalized with the Tommy Randall Memorial Fund, which has been established to raise money to help other cancer patients with medical and non-medical expenses. The Fund has been so successful that the PGA Tour has included it as part of the 2014 PGA Tour schedule. Randall's memory lives on in his hometown, where the city of Naperville has built a memorial statue and garden to honor him. The memorial park is located near the golf course which Randall used to frequent. It includes a sculpture of a golfer teeing off, and a quote from Randall inscribed in the statue’s base: "The harder you work, the luckier you get." Throughout his career, Randall personified the phrase “hard work pays off”, and remains an inspiration for young golfers today. His legacy will continue for many years to come.

Vladimir Semago (b. 1939 in Moscow, Soviet Union) is a Russian politician, political writer and academic. He is known for his publications in the sociology and political sciences fields. He graduated from Moscow State University’s Higher School of Economics in 1964 and has served as a professor at the Institute of Scientific Information for Social Sciences at the Russian Academy of Sciences since 1996. Semago was a long-time member of the Russian parliament, the Council of the Federation, where he was deputy speaker from 2003 to 2011. He also sat on the commission for human rights, civil associations, and religious institutions since 2000. He was one of the early supporters of democratization in Russia and advocated greater human rights standards and open society values. During his time in parliament he fought to liberalize journalism laws, introduce alcohol and drug addiction protection, advance legislation regulating weapons possession, and ensure the right of fair trial. Beginning in the late-1980s, Semago began to write and publish extensively, focusing on the topics of democracy, civil society, and the development of ‘post-communist’ Russia. He published a number of books and dozens of articles in periodicals and got involved in governmental and public initiatives. His works were translated into several foreign languages and some of them were used as textbooks in universities and colleges. Semago got numerous awards and medals for his public activity. Among them were the Order of Honour in 2019, the Order of Merit for the Fatherland (III degree) in 2005 and the Order of Friendship in 2001. He also became a laureate of the Vasiliev Award in 2006 and the Information for Democracy Award in 2004. In 2011, Semago retired from the Council of the Federation. During his time in parliament he was a strong advocate of open society values, human rights and democratic societies. He continues to speak on key contemporary political and social issues both in Russia and abroad. Currently, Semago is a visiting professor at St. Petersburg State University and a Professor of Information Science at the Academy of Social Sciences. He is also a visiting professor at Moscow State Institute of International Relations.

Schizopygopsis is a genus of cyprinid fish that are native to Central and East Asia, from Bhutan and Nepal to the Amur Basin in eastern Russia and northern China. The genus contains over twenty species, most of which inhabit upland rivers and streams with cool to cold water environments. Some species may also enter waters around lakes and the edges of wetlands. The majority of Schizopygopsis species are medium-sized, with adults growing up to 25 cm (9.8 in) in length. They can be identified by their streamlined and laterally compressed bodies, featuring large eyes, powerful jaws and teeth, as well as muscular dorsal and caudal fins. Whilst adults of the species display a gray-brown coloration dorsally, most species also exhibit a distinct color pattern on the sides and belly, often with patterns of blue, green and red. The diet of Schizopygopsis consists mainly of aquatic insects such as midge larvae, crustaceans, and the larvae and eggs of other fish. In turn, the adults and juveniles of Schizopygopsis are consumed by a variety of predators, such as herons and hawks, as well as other fish. Schizopygopsis species may also occasionally enter into spawning migrations. For example, the Schizothorax richardsonii may migrate up to 40 km (25 miles) from their year-round habitats in isolated rivers to reach the tributaries of large lakes. When spawning, adults of this species may form dense aggregations. Upon hatching, larvae of most species drift downstream until they reach nursery habitats of shallower, warmer waters. Like many species of cyprinids, Schizopygopsis species are an important food source for local populations and are widely fished. Thus, there is intense pressure on these species, particularly in areas where capture limits are not regulated. As Schwizopygopsis inhabit relatively narrow ranges, they are susceptible to habitat changes that can affect their limited populations and also increase the risks of overfishing. Therefore, it is widely recommended that management plans be established to conserve these populations. Management plans should include provisions for setting appropriate catch limits and protecting their habitats from both chemical and physical disturbance. Furthermore, research should be conducted to better understand the ecology of these species and the effects of various environmental changes.

The UAB Blazers men's soccer program represents the University of Alabama at Birmingham in National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I men's soccer competition. The program is an independent member of Conference USA and the Southern Conference. The team plays its home matches at West Campus Soccer Field, located in Birmingham, Alabama. The UAB Blazers first fielded a men's soccer program in 1979, competing as a Division II independent member of the NCAA. The team was coached by head coach John Jones, and was funded on a ticket drive with the help of the Birmingham Boys Track Club. The team competed for several seasons before disbanding in 1986. In 1994, UAB announced the relaunch of its men's soccer program. The team once again competed as a Division II independent, and the team's first head coach was Scott Gurney. The team achieved immediate success, reaching the NCAA Division II tournament semifinals in its first season. In 1996, the Blazers reached the NCAA Division II tournament finals, which they won with a 1-0 victory over Oakland University, earning themselves a spot in NCAA Division I. Under head coach Mike Getman, UAB made the NCAA tournament in its first year as a Division I program, advancing to the second round before being eliminated by Duke University. The UAB Blazers have continued to be successful, earning nine NCAA Tournament berths and four Sweet 16 berths since joining Division I in 1997. In 2013, the team advanced to its first-ever NCAA Division I Final Four, narrowly losing in the semi-finals to Maryland. The UAB Blazers have had a successful run under the guidance of head coach Mike Getman and assistant coach Todd Smart. The team has consistently been ranked in the top-25 teams of the NSCAA National Poll and have recently been the recipient of the Conference USA regular season title. The UAB Blazers have consistently produced players who have gone on to play professionally, including Jason Bond, Darren Eales and David Mims. The UAB Blazers have also produced Olympic Gold Medalists, such as Payton Lewis who represented the United States at the Beijing 2008 Olympics. UAB has competed in Conference USA since 2013, making it one of the few independent programs in the league. The Blazers home matches are typically held at the West Campus Soccer Field, located on-campus within walking distance of the UAB campus. The UAB Blazers have established a passionate fanbase, known as the Blazer Girls, who lead chants and support the team throughout the season.
